name: Adrian
bio: Here to show you tips and tricks for your plant needs! 😁

social_posts.post_text:
Testing this out just for fun 😬 I kind of like the idea of using clear water beads as a soilless medium for aesthetic reasons. If you don’t know by now, I’m all about watching them roots develop. I could of left the plant alone where it was previously growing but I know over time I would need to transfer the plant into a larger pot. And for this particular cutting, I decided to just grow it water. So the beads will help prop and keep the plant in place. 

Few tips:
1. Make sure that the beads are fully grown and has soaked up the maximum amount of water it can hold. After I had added water, the beads started to expand some more. It was still absorbing the water and it started to trickle out of the vase. 
2. Make sure to rinse the beads off before using it. This particular one had a scent to it which I felt the plant wouldn’t like. Don’t want to have chemicals lingering in with the plant. 
3. Don’t over fill the the vase with the water beads. As you can see, I was using chopsticks to move some air bubbles around so I can get that invisible effect but the beads kept falling out.
4. And just like with any hydro method, don’t forget to add some fertilizer with every watering. Water beads don’t offer any nutritional value whatsoever. 
5. I don’t think I’ll be doing this method in the long run as you can see, I can’t do a proper flush. Unless I pour out all the beads and rinse the plant, vase, and beads off. But that would just be adding more work to my already 3 hour long watering process. And ain’t nobody got time for that 😝 Just have fun with it!!! 

⚠️ Always be mindful around pets and kids with trying this method out. 

Happy Planting! 💚🪴 
.
.
.
.
.

Just a small trim 🙈😝

Clipping down one of my beasts. Don’t worry I have a special project for these cuttings for the coming month. Got to start now so roots can develop. Plus, it was getting wild and I was lazy to build a moss pole for it to properly climb. 

I know you’ve been seeing plenty of Burle Marx in my reels, I just have so many of them from a previous cutting. I’m telling yah, they grow like weeds! 😆 And they’re easy and accessible to have when it comes to experimenting new growing techniques. 

Happy Planting! 💚🪴 

🌱 #philodendronburlemarx

It looks like I’m going to have to propagate this beauty. The variegation on this particular plant seems to be reverting. Although there is slight variegation on the newest leaf, just to be sure, I’m going to propagate it using a propagation ball before I give it a chop.

When I do this, I like to make sure that the aerial root is active. I determine this by monitoring its growth and checking the color of the root. As the tips give off a yellow/greenish, I know that it’s trying to find something to attach itself to. I will leaf (pun intended 😝) it alone for a few weeks or a little over a month before making the chop.

Til then,
Happy Planting! 💚🪴 
.

Here are some updates on my water beads, also known as “orbeez,” experiment 😊

1. Alocasia Frydek Corms: Unfortunately, the corms didn’t show much growth. Instead of developing roots, I got algae growth😭 Despite creating optimal conditions with a small DIY greenhouse/propbox, heating pad, and grow lights, the desired results were not achieved. In the end, I decided to repot the whole thing and just grow it in plain ol’ leca since my success rate is much higher when I do.

2. Philodendron Burlemarx Cutting: The cutting placed in a vase filled with water beads is still doing well. However, over time, I noticed the beads shrinking and the plant slightly tipping over. With that being said, I don’t see myself doing this long term so a repot will be coming up pretty soon for this fella. 

**I want to mention that I have received comments and DMs expressing concerns about the negative impact of water beads (orbeez) on the environment and potential health risks for children and animals. I understand that not everyone may approve of these methods, and I encourage everyone to be mindful when trying new techniques. I have personally enjoyed this experiment but acknowledge that it’s not suitable for everyone.

But as always…
Happy Planting! 💚🪴 
.

Who doesn’t love a good repot 😊 

This guy was supposed to be a prop and chop project. I even had a prop ball set and ready to go. Roots are looking beautiful too. This cutting was from one of my Aureas that was reverting. So, I wanted to test out if I could cut it back to stimulate some variegation and hopefully get lucky. But hey, I kind of like how it’s growing, and I need more tall plants in my life! So he’ll live as is 😁

Til next time, Happy Planting! 💚🪴

Just as mentioned in my previous post, I planned to do a repot for this guy. While the idea of using orbeez seemed cool, it didn’t work out well for me in the long term. The plant started to tip over as the beads got smaller, and I also noticed that some of the roots easily pulled off. Although there were no signs of root rot, it might have been the beginning stages of it. It was an interesting experiment to try out with a new medium.

For the repotting process, I opted for straight sphagnum moss. Based on my experience, my burlemarx plants seem to thrive well in it. Additionally, I added a pole that was sent to me by @growthiccly It was super easy to assemble and use. Notably, it keeps the moss moist for a longer duration compared to the other DIY poles I have made. If you’re interested in ordering these bad boys, I highly recommend checking them out.

Happy Planting! 💚🪴

Bertha’s aerial roots getting a bit out of hand 😅 On one hand, I’m considering trimming them off, but on the other hand, she seems incredibly content and happy, despite desperately needing a repot. It’s clear that she’s becoming root-bound, but I can’t help but wonder if there’s a reason to disturb her when she’s flourishing so beautifully.

What do y’all think, should I go ahead and prune her aerial roots or should I let them be? 🤔

Happy Planting! 💚🪴 

🌱 #monsterathaiconstellation

Nothing crazy, just a small trim 🙈😁

I’ve been working on rebuilding my monstera army. Over the past few months, I had to downsize my collection and part ways with several plants. Some were sold, while others were given to friends and family. 

Heads up, I may not be posting as much over the next few months. Just dealing with some personal matters that require some attention. But don’t worry, I’ll do my best to answer back any questions you may have. So feel free to hit me up ☺️ And I will apologize in advance for any delayed responses 🫶🏼🫶🏼🫶🏼

As always, thank you for the continued love and support! 
Happy Planting! 💚🪴

Monstera chop and prop! 🫶🏼

As mentioned in my previous post, I made the decision to rebuild my monstera army. The setup was incredibly simple. I just cut the stems and placed the cuttings into glass jars filled with leca. I’ve noticed that my cuttings tend to root more quickly when they are growing in glass containers. In the past, I have used plastic containers, but for some reason, it takes ages for the roots to emerge.

Additionally, I ended up using kitchen scissors, which is something I almost never do. Unfortunately, I seem to have misplaced my shears that I typically use for cutting. The cuts come out much cleaner when proper sharp cutters are utilized.

Happy Planting! 💚🪴 
.

Hi! 👋🏼☺️

I know it’s been a while 😅 How are all of you? I hope you and your plants have been thriving more than ever!!! I’ll be popping in sporadically. I must tell you, I miss you all very much!

Anyways, I had to give Bertha a chop yesterday. She was just getting too big for my space. This is just the top cutting. Before I placed her in water, I let her dry for up to 3 hours to help her callus over. This will reduce the risk of stem rot forming. I think she looks happy, but she’s probably mad that I had to trim her, especially since she’s my oldest plant.

Happy Planting! 💚🪴

This is 35 🙇🏻‍♂️

I just want to say thank you for all the love and support you’ve shown on my plant page. I honestly didn’t think it get to where it was if it wasn’t for you all. Y’all continue to inspire me everyday. And for that, I appreciate and love you all! Cheers to another year! 🥰🫶🏼

Here are a few more cuttings I made of my Thai Con plant. I’m super pleased that none of them showed any signs of stem rot, especially considering the close internode spacing. If any had developed, my chances of saving the plant would have been very slim.

These cuttings had such long aerial roots that it was a challenge to place them in the vase. As you can see, I noticed that some of the aerial roots started to show some signs of rot. So, I decided to simply chop them off. Hopefully, with these recent cuts, they can focus on developing roots in other areas.

Happy Planting! 💚🪴 

#monsterathaiconstellation

Update on my Monstera Thai top cutting! Small rootage happening! 😆

If you saw my previous reels, I cut this baddie about 3 weeks ago on September 4th, and it started to develop some roots. Normally, I’d wait until the roots are at least 5 inches long before transferring it to a pot, but this time, I decided to grow it hydroponically. This method is the same as rooting in just straight water, only difference is that the roots get to grab on to the leca which can help promote bigger leaves.

Let me show you my usual setup. I always begin with a bottom layer of leca and top it off with sphagnum moss. Additionally, I positioned the root so that I can see it from the vase. This helps me monitor its growth and gives me peace of mind as time goes on. I’ve been using this method for over 3 years now, and it has never failed me. I particularly enjoy using hydroponics for my monsteras and alocasias. Please note that when using hydroponics, you must add fertilizer during your watering because the moss and leca do not provide any nutrients for the plants. I prefer to use TezulaPlants’ 20-20-20 fertilizer, which I order through their Etsy store. It eliminates the guesswork when it comes to fertilizing, and I’ve been a satisfied customer for over 3 years.

Till next time…
Happy Planting! 💚🪴 

🌱 #monsterathaiconstellation

Watering Globes!!!! 😁😁😁😁

These will serve as my method of plant care during my two-week vacation. I’ll rely on these watering globes to ensure my babies stay hydrated. My typical watering schedule involves tending to my plants once a week, about every 7 days or even longer. The ones in soil tends to dry out rather quickly, those will be the only plants I’d have to really worry about. Currently, I have about 6 of them in a soil mix. I have the globes set up one on the poles and and on bottom. Make make sure to conduct a test to ensure that the water doesn’t pour out too quickly. The goal is for the water to flow out as slowly as possible. You may need to adjust the positioning of the globe a bit to make this work. 

While I’m away, one of my closest friends (who, I must admit, does not have any knowledge about plants 😝) will visit once a week to refill these globes. The fantastic thing about these specific globes is that they can be easily filled from the top since they are topless. While it might not be the most ideal watering method, I wanted to ensure that my plants receive at least some water while I’m away and make the process as convenient as possible for my friend. For those in hydroponics, it’s even simpler—she only needs to fill them to at least 1/3 or halfway from the bottom with water. Additionally, I have all my lights and fan set up on a timer. We will see how they look after this vacation 😅

🪴 Globes can be found through my Amazon link under my bio, incase y’all interested. 

Till next time…
Happy Planting! 💚🪴 
.

Following up from my previous post:

After placing your corms in the prop box/greenhouse, I prefer situating them atop a heating pad while exposing them to my grow lights for a minimum of 15-24 hours each day. This not only accelerates root development but also fosters humidity, particularly favored by tropical plants. In a few weeks, I should see some roots emerging! 😆😆

Till next time….
Happy Planting! 💚🪴

Air layer with me ☺️

Utilizing air layering as a propagation technique has proven to be a game-changer. This method ensures a seamless transition for the plant, preventing any shock during its growth. Remaining connected to the mama plant allows it to flourish, while roots quietly take shape within the ball. When these roots reach just over an inch, it’s time for the gentle snip. Stay tuned for updates in a few weeks! 😁

✨ Incase you are interested: Propagation Balls that you see here, can be found through my Amazon link under my bio. 

Till next time….
Happy Planting! 💚🪴 
.

Chopping time 😁🌱

A few weeks after air layering this beauty, I’ve observed promising signs of root growth. Initially planning to wait for further development, I noticed she started leaning due to insufficient support from the top, resulting in a bend in the stem. Despite this, the activated roots give me confidence that she will thrive. The setup mirrors that of my other plants, with a bottom layer of leca and a top layer of sphagnum moss.

Till next time….
Happy Planting! 💚🪴

The damage is done 🙈

Went on a crazy cutting spree on my Aureas 😬
I’m trying to rebuild my monstera army back up again. After the cuts, I prefer letting them sit for an hour or two before placing them in water. This brief interval helps initiate the callousing process on the stems, reducing the risk of stem rot. I was able to propagate 11 cuttings from both mama monsteras. Wish them luck! 🤞🏼

As always…
Happy Planting!🪴

Following up from my previous post 🪴☺️

After deciding to chop my aureas, I initially considered experimenting with some of the 11 cuttings. However, decided to not mess around and just do my usual setup. The combination of leca and sphagnum moss has consistently proven effective for rooting my monsteras. Since the mama plants thrived in this setup, I saw no reason to change it. I’ve stuck with this medium exclusively for a considerable time, and approximately 90% of my plants flourish in it. A notable advantage is the rare encounter with pests—mostly just a few fungus gnats, but that’s easily managed with sticky traps. In around two weeks, sometimes even less, I’ll typically observe some root growth. I’ll keep y’all posted as time goes on!!! 😁

Til then…
Happy Planting!🪴
.

When I was consistent, I noticed the aerial roots attaching to the pole and the growth of larger leaves. It’s time to step up my game and improve my watering routine 😤😤

Having trouble with those hard water stains on your plants? Well look no further…I’m kidding 😅 However, I do have a solution for you! 

I like to take my plants into the tub on watering days and run them under the shower. This ensures they are fully rinsed and free of dust. The only problem is that I don’t wipe them down before placing them back in their spots. This leaves (pun intended) the plants dealing with water stains on their foliage. To address this issue, I use Dr. Bronner’s Pure Castile Soap. It’s super simple – just a few drops of the soap (a little goes a long way) into a small bowl with added water, and that’s it! I use a cloth to wipe them down, and although it may take a few wipes, eventually, you’ll get those stains out, leaving your leaves clean and shiny! 🤩✨ In case you’re wondering, I’ve never experienced any soapy residue on the plants, which is why I stick to using just a few drops. 

Til next time… Happy Planting!🪴
.
.
.

Here to show you tips and tricks for your plant needs! 😁
